title: Conversion Prediction
summary:
# Summary: Predicting User Purchases from Clickstream Data in Fashion E-Commerce

This research paper addresses a critical challenge in e-commerce: distinguishing between users who will make a purchase ("buyers") and those who are merely browsing ("window shoppers") based on their clickstream behavior. The authors present a novel dataset, benchmark existing models, and propose a new neural architecture that achieves state-of-the-art performance.

## The Business Problem

The fashion industry has experienced extraordinary growth in online retail, with nearly 25% of fashion transactions now occurring digitally. However, the vast majority of website sessions come from users with weak buying intention. Being able to identify potential buyers in real-time would allow fashion retailers to implement effective "next best action" policies, personalize user experiences, and ultimately increase conversion rates. Small improvements in e-commerce conversion rates can translate into massive revenue uplifts for businesses.

The core challenge stems from two factors: the extremely low frequency of conversion events (typically only around 5.5% of sessions end in purchases) and the inherent noisiness of browsing data. This severe class imbalance makes accurate classification particularly difficult.

## The Tooso Fashion Clickstream Dataset

The authors contributed a substantial new dataset called the Tooso Fashion Clickstream Dataset (TFCD), containing real user session data from a major European e-commerce fashion website with over €1 billion in annual turnover. The dataset covers sessions from June 29 to July 18, 2018, and includes 5.4 million events across 443,652 sessions from 212,037 unique users.

Each session contains click events with associated metadata including timestamps, event types (view, click, detail, add-to-cart, remove-from-cart, and buy), and product information. The data was collected through a web pixel in compliance with privacy regulations, with all identifiers doubly-hashed to prevent re-identification.

For benchmarking purposes, the researchers created a "symbolized" version of the dataset where each session is reduced to a sequence of integers representing event types. After cleaning (removing sessions with fewer than 10 or more than 200 events) and balancing through random downsampling, the final benchmark dataset contains 7,176 BUY sessions and 14,352 NOBUY sessions.

Analysis of the dataset revealed interesting patterns: BUY sequences have more than double the number of add-to-cart actions compared to NOBUY sequences, while NOBUY sequences contain more detail events—suggesting window shoppers spend more time examining products without committing to purchase.

## Models Tested and Results

The researchers evaluated five different approaches, progressing from simple baselines to sophisticated neural architectures:

The n-gram Naive Bayes model, treating clickstreams as bag-of-n-grams, achieved 82.1% accuracy. The Markov Chain model, which captures state transition probabilities between events, improved substantially to 88.2% accuracy, demonstrating that the sequence of events matters significantly.

The LSTM Language Model, following the approach from Rakuten Labs, achieved 90.9% accuracy by replacing the Markov transition matrix with recurrent neural network probabilities. This represented a meaningful improvement over the generative Markov approach.

The authors' novel contribution came in two variants of a Seq2Label (S2L) discriminative classifier. This architecture uses an LSTM to encode the entire sequence, then pools the hidden states to make a binary prediction, rather than modeling each class separately.

The S2L with average pooling achieved 92.7% accuracy, while the S2L using only the last LSTM output reached 93.2% accuracy—the best result in the study. The difference between these two pooling strategies is statistically significant at the 99% confidence level.

The last-output pooling approach trained faster and with fewer parameters, suggesting that users exhibit distinctive clicking behavior immediately before completing a purchase. However, the average pooling variant may prove superior for early prediction on incomplete sessions, which represents an important direction for future work.

## Future Directions

The authors outline several promising extensions. First, they plan to adapt the architectures for incremental classification as sessions unfold in real-time, rather than classifying complete sessions after the fact. Second, they intend to incorporate additional metadata including inter-click dwell times and fashion product features derived from images and text. Third, they are exploring alternative approaches including visibility graphs from complex systems physics, autoencoders for treating conversion as anomaly detection, and multi-task learning objectives that jointly predict the next state and the final classification.

The authors emphasize their commitment to open science, planning to release the dataset under a research-friendly license to enable reproducible benchmarking—similar to how Fashion MNIST became a standard benchmark for computer vision in fashion.
